message: Anybody wanting background on bitcoin, check out the Russ Roberts EconTalk podcast interview (extended notes as well) with Gavin Andresen here: http://www.econtalk.org/archives/2011/04/andresen_on_bit.html

This show has a ton of ground to cover -- but we want to know what you think about bitcoin, the world's only international and non-government-regulated currency. Do you own any bitcoin? Would you consider buying some? How do you think it could be used for good or evil?
Ask Gavin about his upcoming visit to the CIA in June.
Ubitex is my little project: buy and sell Bitcoins for cash-in-hand. http://ubitex.org
Also see http://media.witcoin.com/ and http://bitcoin.witcoin.com/ for other Bitcoin-related contents.
Sorry to say Bitcoin, but I still don't get it. I'll watch the show and save my questions, but if anyone cares to break it down for me, please feel free to respond.
@Mpressme (& others) -- You might want to watch TWIST guest Gavin Andresen in this video as he breaks down the bitcoin concept pretty well. http://blip.tv/file/4771178
Hey guys.
Welcome, executive producer Octavian!
0. will try it though. interesting.
and since 3rd parties that exchange goods or money for bitcoins would have your real identity, you can trace back all transactions used by that bitcoin address.
looking forward to this. long time fan of twist and interested in bitcoin since about 1 month ago
@cilianobriain when did you buy them?
So what is your strategy?
Awesome, @cillianobriain
How many bitcoins do you guys own?
So what should you do to secure it?
just trying out something new. no real strategy
in basic theory it makes sense. it seems to me economy is more complicated than just the bitcoin system. tyler makes good points since I think bitcoin has a strong ideological basis.
~20 bitcoins
maybe 2 weeks ago. there was somethign called coinpal i think. used paypal but shut down now
Welcome, Executive Producer Eien! Good points
thx
bitcoin is susceptible to deflation
all transactions on bitcoin are publicly viewable. while your identity is represented as a bitcoin address, you can still scrape the info out there to find transaction patterns.
tyler is right on!
that's just moving the decimal, it's still a finite resource whose intrinsic value will rises with scarcity+demand.
they are stored in a wallet.dat file
you have to manually archive it yourself.
if you lose that file, your bitcoins are gone. no getting them back
So, is this a ponzi scheme?
i wouldn't characterize it that way. i think the bitcoin people have good intentions. it's just economics.
that file is very vulnerable
Yes, the philosophy behind this is key -- Gavin and Amir talked about this in the pre-interviews
it's a william gibson/cyberpunk world
i would. but I watch nearly every twist anyway.
@cillianobriain :) What would you want to know that didn't get covered today?
Would you guys tune in for a follow-up bitcoin show?

for bitcoin to be useful needs to be accepted more widely. maybe could cover more about the bitcoin economy. companies that accept bitcoin. micropayments? give it a year perhaps and see what happens. all or nothing as they just said.
great show guys! we need to get some shark tanks going soon and ask jasons.
thanks
bye
